questions: State one difference between autotrophic and heterotrophic mode of nutrition.
answers: Autotrophic nutrition in which organisms prepare their own food from simple inorganic sources like carbon dioxide and water. Heterotrophic nutrition in which organisms do not synthesise their own food and is dependent on the autotrophic for obtaining complex organic substance for nutrition.

questions: Where do plants get each of the raw materials required for photosynthesis ?
answers: The raw materials for photosynthesis are carbon dioxide and water. Terrestrial plants get carbon dioxide from environment and water from the soil. Aquatic plants obtain CO2 that is present in dissolved form in water. Water is simply absorbed by the parts of plant submerged in water.

questions: In Nutrition a necessity for an organism? Discuss.
answers: Nutrition is required to provide energy for the various metabolic processes in the body. It is essential for the growth of new cells and repair or replacement of worn out cells. It is needed to develop resistance against various diseases.

questions: Write any two events that occur during photosynthesis.
answers: Two events that occur during photosynthesis are :  Absorption of light energy by chlorophyll.  Conversion of light energy into chemical energy and splitting of water molecules into hydrogen and oxygen.

questions: Which is the internal energy reserve in plants Do animals have the same energy reserve ?
answers: Plants have starch as the storage carbohydrate which act as internal energy reserve. But animals have glycogen as internal energy reserve.

questions: What would happen if green plants disappear from earth?
answers: If all plants were to be removed from the surface of Earth, there will be excess of carbon dioxide cause there are no plants to convert it into oxygen. Green plants are the sources of energy for all organism, all herbivores will die due to starvation.

questions: Why does herbivores have longer, small intestine than carnivores ?
answers: Herbivores have longer small intestine to allow the cellulose to be digested completely. Herbivores have longer intestine than carnivores to digest grass. The intestine would host many small bacteria that process and breakdown cellulose into glucose.

questions: Mention the site of complete digestion in our body. Name the end products formed on complete digestion of carbohydrates, proteins and fats.
answers: Site of Complete digestion : Small intestine in alimentary canal. End products formed are : Proteins ¾® Amino acids Carbohydrates ¾® Simple sugars Fats ¾® Fatty acids + Glycerol.

questions: How is small intestine designed to absorb digested food?
answers: The digested food is taken up by the walls of the intestine. The inner lining of the small intestine has numerous finger-like projections called villi which increase the surface area for absorption. The villi are richly supplied with blood vessels which take the absorbed food to each and every cell of the body. 2

questions: How are fats digested in our bodies? Where does this process take place.
answers: Fats are digested in the small intestine. The secretion of liver, called bile, breaks down the large globules of fats into smaller globules. This is called emulsification of fats. The bile also makes the medium alkaline so that the pancreatic enzyme containing lipase further digest fats to form fatty acids.

questions: What are final products of carbohydrates, proteins and fats after their digestion ?

questions: Explain the significance of peristaltic movement that occur all along the gut during digestion.
answers: It is necessary to move the food in a regulated manner along the digestive tube so that it can be processed properly in each part. The lining of canal has muscles that contract rhythmically in order to push the food forward. 1 This is known as peristaltic movement.

questions: Why does the medium become acidic in mouth ? What is the ill effect of this acidic medium ? How can this be prevented ?

questions: What function is served by the following :  Gastric Sphincter ?  Anal Sphincter ?
answers: Gastric Sphincter : Controls the release of food from the stomach to small intestine.  Anal Sphincter : Controls the release of undigested waste from the rectum through the anus.

questions: Some finger like projections are present in the inner wall of small intestine. Write their names ? Why are they important ?

questions: State the necessary conditions for auto trophic nutrition and name the by product. Mention the source of this by product.
answers: Conditions necessary for autotrophic nutrition are : Sunlight, Chlorophyll, Carbon dioxide and water. By products are carbohydrates in the form of starch and oxygen.

questions: Describe heterotrophic mode of nutrition and give its examples. Name the three types of this nutrition.
